It really is just this easy to identify your enemy...     (they are the stupid ones, suggesting all the obviously stupid ideas)

Only a complete imbecile would try to accomplish modifying the temperature chemically, by putting crap into the atmosphere...   rather than mechanically, by using orbital shades / reflectors.

The mechanical method utilizes the well understood principals of thermal dynamics, where blocking some of the sunlight that falls on the planet would lower the temperature, and reflecting more sunlight onto the planet would raise the temperature.   Simple, well understood, 100% reversible, and works regardless of the cause of the unfavorable changes to be corrected.

So why would you want to put crap into the atmosphere that you can't easily remove, when that method is unproven, not well understood, and completely unnecessary?

text: Man's impact isn't nearly as cynical as it's been demonized to be. CO¬≤ has increased L.A.I. (leaf area index) worldwide by 70% over just 30 years. Every time the Earth has had an abundance of CO¬≤ in the atmosphere, and the climate was significantly warmer, life has thrived. In contrast, when CO¬≤ and global temperatures have declined, life has struggled to survive. CO¬≤ was on a steady decline before the industrial revolution. The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere was reduced by about 90% during the last 150 million years. If this trend had continued, CO2 would have inevitably fallen to levels that threaten the survival of plants, which REQUIRE a minimum of 150 ppm to survive. Considering the atmosphere was down to 280 ppm, pre-industrial revolution. I'd say we're damn lucky we discovered the benefits of burning fossil fuels.

text:
Geoengineering, making tomorrow's pollution profitable today using yesterday's technology. 
Climate change is not the existential threat, our egos are.

Carbon Dioxide Effects Research and Assessment Program, Workshop on the Global Effects of Carbon Dioxide from Fossil Fuels. 
"At this point we have provided order-of-magnitude estimates for a variety of potential technical fixes [Geoengineering] that have been proposed, seriously or otherwise, for dealing with a rising atmospheric CO2 concentration, should that concentration rise ever be viewed as an imminent ecological emergency." 

Climate change has become extremely profitable for the big polluters.
They have no interest in stopping it, quite the opposite infact.
Why stop something that has potential to increase business revenues in the order of magnitudes. while providing stable recurring revenue streams for years, decades, to come.

"The fight against greenhouse gases offers huge opportunities for profit. In order to promote this idea, some friends and I have founded the Carbon War Room. We think that one way to look at climate protection is to regard it as a business model, because our only option to stop climate change is for industry to make money from it." Richard Branson (2012) (Climate Change is a Huge Opportunity, Spiegel Online)

The climate crises never was about saving the environment, it's about saving economies of scale.

Fuel to the Fire: How Geoengineering Threatens to Entrench Fossil Fuels and Accelerate the Climate Crisis¬†highlights how the urgency and scale of the climate crisis are being exploited to push ideas like carbon dioxide removal (CDR) and solar radiation management (SRM)‚Äîonce relegated to the fringes of the climate debate‚Äîinto the mainstream. It examines the fossil fuel industry‚Äôs long history and continued role in the development and promotion of key geoengineering concepts and technologies, and it exposes the numerous ways these technologies serve to protect the industry and promote new emissions from fossil fuels.

"should that concentration rise ever be viewed as an imminent ecological emergency." US Department of Energy, (1977).

text: Wow! This came up in my youtube feed. Couldn't get past the -carbon dioxide is at the highest levels in the history of the world. Did you guys do even the tiniest bit of research before prepping this. CO2 levels are LOW. At under 250 ppm, plants no longer conduct photosynthesis. They all die. At least, 1,000 ppm would be much better. The flowering plants, from which we derive most of our food, emerged at around 8,000 ppm CO2. CO2 is NOT causing climate change and the temps have NOT gone up 2 degrees per century due to humans. The weather temps were considerably hotter in the 1920s and 30s and mid 1800s. The climate is indeed changing. It's getting colder and fast. Before making a documentary, it would be prudent to actually understand the science: solar cycles - both long and short, solar forcing, ocean circulation, the Earth's electric circuit, Atlantic conveyor, and WORLD HISTORY. text:
Doomsday prophecy BULLSHIT. 

There us NO increase in extreme weather events, even the lobby organization IPCC says this.

There is NO increase in the rate of sea level rise. Increasing rise is an hypothesis yet to be proven. 

Warming LEADS CO2 rise, NOT the other way around, and earth is currently coming out of a LACK of CO2. 

Hotter weather means MORE humidity, not less. This leads to more rain AND more snow building glaciers at polar environments. 

To melt the ice on greenland at the highest rate (summer south) ever observed, but constantly 24/7/365, and without snow, which is impossible, it would STILL take 6000 years. That's how  much ice there is. 

There is NO decrease in regeneration of ice, nor is the melt-off abnormal. At all. To raise alarms of ice melting in the south of an ice-colossus in the middle of summer is not just dumb but obviously intentionally highly misleading.

There is a VERY distinct DECREASE in forrest fires in most parts of the world, especially in the US. 

In the last 20 years, there has been an ENORMOUS increase in forrest growth, about a whole continents worth of trees, according to NASA satellite  surveying.

text:
It would be interesting to know what happened in the Arctic during the 10,800 BCE abrupt climate change. We know there were two ice sheets - smaller Cordilleran and bigger Laurentide on North America. The Laurentide perhaps 3 - 4 km thick at some places. 

There was a paper published in Feb 2018 in The Journal of Geology about extraordinary biomass burning around 10,800 BCE. It is fascinating.

Adjusted quote: "Around 10,800 BCE, likely within the span of 21 years between 10,818 BCE and 10,797 BCE, ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 (area as big as the US), burned. The concentrations of soot, used to estimate the global amount of biomass burned, suggest that wildfires around 10,800 BCE consumed considerably more biomass than during the K-Pg extinction event."

If interested the links are https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695703?journalCode=jg for part 1 and https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695704 for part 2. 

It would be interesting to calculate how much CO2 must have been released when ‚àº9% of world terrestrial biomass on ‚àº10 million km2 burned. The wildfires on 70,000 km¬≤ in Australia this year are estimated to release about 900 million tons of CO2, which equals to double the country's total yearly fossil fuel emissions."

Perhaps CO2 released by burning of ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 might have contributed to melting of Cordilleran and Laurentide ice sheets? At present CO2 melts ice in Arctic, Greenlad, Antarctica so we can assume it should have been melting ice also around 10,800 BCE as well. 

There is a puzzling energy paradox. Melting of ice sheets happened during very cold period, so it should not have happened.

What mechanisms or combination of might have caused rapid melting of several kilometres thick ice sheets?

One simple physics principle is that the weight of several millions cubic kilometres of ice pushes the continent down. Heavy ice depresses the surface, at times pushing it below sea level, making the ice sheets to get in contact with warmer ocean, causing the ice sheets to retreat and stabilizing the system. Destabilize the system enough with a powerful external factor and things start moving quickly. 

Recent scientific papers start to provide more and more evidence that an external fast acting factor was in effect around 10,800 BCE. 

The paper published in March 2020 in Nature provides evidence of cosmic impact at Syria, coeval with impacts that deposited high-temperature meltglass, melted microspherules, and/or platinum at >50 sites on four continents around 10,800 BCE. Link to the article https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w

Impact on several kilometres thick ice sheet in Canada would not have left a permanent crater imprinted in the ground but more likely a depression filled with water which today would be in the form of a lake. 

There are several candidates for comet fragments impacts on ice sheet in Canada around 10,800 BCE. One of them possibly in Great Lakes area, perhaps the Saginaw Bay, Michigan // Lake Nippon // Manicouagan Reservoir // Gulf of Saint Lawrence // 

It is suggested it started in direction from Western coast to Eastern coast. 

It would be interesting to check the known impact craters in the world for a possible "string impacts. Just a few candidates - Rochechouart crater in France, Saint Martin crater in Manitoba, Obolon crater in Ukraine, Red Wing crater in North Dakota. If there is any researcher or enthusiast out there able to get some funding go for it.:-)

If you have not seen a string impact video please check the well-known Shoemaker‚ÄìLevy 9 string impacts on Jupiter in July 1994 on BBC Studios YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgOTcIfU75Y

As mentioned in the March 2020 paper in Nature (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w) there might have been multiple airbursts/impacts across at least four continents. These are proposed to have resulted from a one of a series of short-period, active comets known to break up frequently and to shed dozens to thousands of fragments that are 10 to 1000‚Äâm‚Äâin diameter, each capable of producing catastrophic airburst/impacts. The largest cometary debris clusters are proposed to be capable of causing thousands of airbursts within a span of minutes across one entire hemisphere of Earth. An encounter with such a million-km-wide debris cluster would be thousands of times more probable than a collision with a 100-km-wide comet or a 10-km asteroid.

text:
It's the measure of a collectively sick society when the concept of "geo engineering" is more socially acceptable than something like drastically reducing consumption and production of non-necessary items (e.g. A thousand different model of cars with a new model every year, a thousand different phones, etc) and production includes voluntarily controlling our population.

First of all, there is a major delusion and myth that is a large hindrance to rationally tackling this crisis, and that is the myth of "techno-optimism", namely how 99% of people, despite absolutely zero empirical evidence to suggest its even possible, walk around ignorantly believing that technology will miraculously solve this issue, all the while, ironically forgetting that technology, especially short sighted techno-fixes, are what largely created this crisis to begin with.  The issue goes much deeper than that however, down to the very basis of civilization itself.

Without exception, every single civilization since agriculture began 10,000 years ago, has collapsed and largely due to, if not entirely due to, environmental degradation, and it's only hubris that makes us believe our civilization is any different.  It's anthropology 101 (I have a bachelor's in anthropology, PhD in molecular neuropharmacology that I recently completed), that civilization cannot exist without agriculture, and that as far as we know, we've yet to see a single example in all of civilized history, of a truly sustainable means of Agriculture.  For instance, soil samplestaken from layers predating the Spanish invasion of Central America demonstrates conclusively that thrle Aztec had just about completely destroyed the nutrients and productive capacity of their soil and that had the Spanish never arrived, their civilization most likely would have collapsed like the majority of civilizations, because of environmental degradation.  We know now that our modern agriculture has destroyed the soil on an even more thorough level to the point of rendering our soil basically as dead material in which we have to spray petri-chemicals upon to even get crops to grow (and BTW, organic agriculture, which has no proof of being sustainable in the longterm, cannot come close to feeding the world's excessive population).  What this demonstrates is that whether zero technology is utilized, or all the advanced technology we have today is used, Agriculture CANNOT BE RENDERED SUSTAINABLE. If civilization cannot exist 2ithout agriculture, then it follows that civilization itself is inherently unsustainable.  So you see, this crisis must force us to question the very underlying myths of our civilization, namely that we're someone different or apart from a history of civilization failing without exception, and the myth of linear human progress.  On another level, we also have to ask whether civilization and technology have been a NET gain for our species. For example, everyone likes to defer to medical science as an example 9f civilization and its benefits, but that medical science only applies to those who can afford it first of all, and if that medical science requires a destructive apparatus that has completely poisoned our air, food, and water and has unleashed an epidemic of industrial diseases like cancer than we cannot cure even when you can afford it, can that really be considered a NET benefit.... When medical science cannot even solve the side effects produced by its own creation?

I strongly sugge anyone doubting me to take five minutes and Google an essay by Jared Diamond (author of the famous book "Guns, Germs, and Steel") called "The Worst Mistake in the History of the Human Race" which scientifically lays out how civilization hasn't been a net benefit to our physical as well as mental health, has not made us happier, doesn't make us more materially affluent (a book called "The Original Affluent Society" by anthropologist Marshall Sahlins makes this point in detail) and has basically destroyed the long term viability of our species.

Basically, we need to drop any notions that we can somehow solve the greatest threat facing our species and somehow maintain our egregiously excessive and illogical way of life too... We can either have a viable, sustainable existence or our precious iPhone, but not both.... I just hope we're mature enough to make the correct choice...

text:
Geoengineering is a stellar example of the ignorant, religious-like faith and techno-optimism that has so many incorrectly believing that technology will miraculously solve the inevitable environmental crisis when it absolutely will not and there's absolutely zero empirical evidence to suggest otherwise.  First off, when a society is more willing to resort Geoengineering, yet another techno fix in a long line of techno fixes that created the environmental crisis to begin with, than to simply reduce consumption and production (perhaps the two easiest and guaranteed methods of tackling this issue), there's a profound disturbance in our thinking.

The undeniable fact is that since civilization first emerged with domestication 10,000 years ago, literally every civilization prior to ours has collapsed and largely due to, if not entirely due to, environmental degradation. It's only hubris, ignorance, and sloth that makes us believe we're any different. What that history of failure means though, is that as a species we have yet to identify any means of making civilized existence environmentally sustainable.  Civilization cannot exist without agriculture, and unfortunately agriculture is inherently sustainable, as whether there's absolutely zero advanced technology involved as in ancient civilizations, or all the advanced technology involved as with the present, we are incapable of making agriculture sustainable and there's a growing consensus among scientists that NOTHING can ever make agriculture environmentally sustainable... Meaning civilization itself can and will never be sustainable.  And despite the completely unfounded belief in many that a technology will miraculously solve this problem, the truth is that technology CANNOT solve this problem and in fact has created it.

For instance, there's literally not enough lithium on the entire planet to convert all the vehicles ALREADY IN EXISTENCE to electric power, let alone for future production.

There's literally not enough fine grade silica of the quality required to create all the solar panels necessary just to meet CURRENT electrical demand.  And even if we  had the silica necessary, we'd have to cover every usable surface of the earth in those solar panels just to meet CURRENT electrical demand... Meaning there'd be no land left for growing food.

So you see, no amount of green energy or technology will solve this problem, the only thing that will solve it is a profound, radical and fundamental questioning and reassessment of every facet or our current existence, including such ideas as voluntary population control and asking whether the capitalist paradigm of infinite economic expansion and production can realistically exist on a planet and reality limited by finite resources.  Basically, anyone thinking that we can solve the environmental crisis without sacrifice and ith keeping everything about our lives the same as it is currently is fooling themselves.

text:
Might be feasible eventually... Gasoline is relatively expensive.

Producing gasoline requires a lot of complex infrastructure & machinery, extremely expensive oil exploration, drilling, transportation (high maintenance cost oil tankers, pipelines and tank trucks) as well as complicated and power hungry oil refineries. Oil companies spend literally couple of trillion dollars annually in order to produce gasoline, diesel and kerosine - and we quite willingly cover that two trillion dollar cost (plus hundreds of billions of dollars in profits for the oil companies) every year when we buy gasoline at the petrol station or pay for flight tickets. 

Carbon Engineering's production units/factories could be built closer to the end customers reducing transportation costs significantly. Also their "raw material" (CO2) and (H2O) are practically free. Carbon Engineering might one day be compensated/paid for removing CO2 from the atmosphere resulting in negative price for one of their raw materials. Furthermore their production units would likely be less expensive to build and operate than e.g. offshore drilling rigs and oil refineries.

text:
How foolish of man to think he can control the planet to this level. -- I'm not saying the entirety of global warming is a hoax. But what I am definitely saying is that various leftists factions around the globe have used it as a fulcrum to attack free market capitalism and advance the cause of power centralization and decimation of individual freedom. And the propaganda campaign is fierce!! 
-
It doesn't take a rocket scientist to see the huge problems with most of the "technologies" proposed in this documentary. For instance. If you run a HUGE fan to suck air into a system to comb out C02, just the power consumed by the fan would likely generate more carbon than the Rube Goldberg device is removing. And then, if any energy is spent in some sort of catalytic or heat based extraction process, MORE carbon footprint. And are any heavy metals or other toxins being used in the process? Because it's going to be a gargantuan effort if it's going to make ANY difference. 
-

This all points to the need for clean energy production, achievable through LFTR nuclear reactors ... which ironically, this documentary didn't even touch on. - Why? POLITICS! 

LFTR technology is being developed by the Chinese, but the Western world is too steeped in cronyism to abandon Uranium based nuclear energy and fossil fuels and invest the billions it will take to get LFTR off the ground. - Once you can make clean power, you can run these goofy machines without the carbon feedback loop issue. -- So then, we'll just be left with the fairly obvious truth that despite how powerful man is, the Earth is a BIG PLACE and we lack the resources to affect this planet very much. -- Think about it. We'd need to run machines to effectively negate ALL OF MANS OTHER ACTIVITIES, THUS FAR! The land consumption alone is staggering! 
-
Take a trans-oceanic flight sometime and get a feel for just how expansive Earth is and then tell me that a few thousand fans and Dr. Seuss machines are going to make the difference of a fart in a tornado!

text: Actually, the timber industries improve forest growth by removing dead trees with Root Rot which will spread and kill surrounding trees. The removal of both dead and healthy trees maintains overgrowth and ultimately prevents mass forest fires that would otherwise destroy entire forests spanning several acres. Like in California for example. Their laws restricting timber industries from collecting fallen and standing dead trees and reducing the number of healthy trees they're permitted to cut down per hectare has had terrible consequences we've observed over the past 2-3 decades. Besides, CO¬≤ has increased L.A.I. (leaf area index) worldwide by 70% over just 30 years. CO¬≤ was on a steady decline before the industrial revolution. The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere was reduced by about 90% during the last 150 million years. If this trend had continued CO2 would have inevitably fallen to levels that threaten the survival of plants, which require a minimum of 150 ppm to survive. Considering the atmosphere was down to 280 ppm, pre-industrial revolution. I'd say we're damn lucky we discovered the benefits of burning fossil fuels. Man's impact isn't nearly as cynical as it's been demonized to be.

text: Because the trees will eventually die and place most of the carbon back into the atmosphere - especially if trees are planted poorly or only one species is planted it will only increase it becoming a carbon source. For a very short time I studied tropical rainforests in Guyana and most of the evidence pointed to them having no to little effect on C02 levels. It becomes a carbon sink for 60 years then releases over 90% of sequestered carbon back to become a carbon source. Problems with large deforestation speeds up forests emitting C02; however, simply planting or replanting a bunch of trees is not an overall effective solution.

Atmospheric solar reflective engineering and direct air capture represent the nexus of militaristic and corporate opportunism for a problem that cannot be solved by high tech engineering alone. Negative Emissions technology that proposes to sequester carbon "underground" through down hole pumping ignores the fact that CO2 is actually needed by plants to grow at the surface, to produce carbohydrates, to build soil carbon through photosynthesis. text: Yes. The ships spray salt water mist, which allows more water droplets to condense into clouds. If the air is too clean clouds can't form even though the humidity is high enough. But when you introduce starting points for the bubbles, for example dust, mentos or engine exhaust particles, a lot of bubbles form very quickly.

text: We have to do everything we can with what we already know works, namely, renewable energy and electric cars.  Coal is the overwhelming largest source of CO2 emissions, and thank god, most coal power plants in this country are already closing due to fracking and renewables.  But this isn't enough.  We have to eliminate all CO2 emissions as soon as possible.  The sad reality is that, at least in the US, this means that solutions must be implemented at the government level.  We must vote for politicians who will take this crisis seriously.  The Republican party is seeped in climate denial currently, having been bought off by many of the major oil and gas companies.  There is almost zero climate leadership from anyone in their party, despite the fact that the Republican party once was the party of environmental conservation even up until the time of Reagan.  Every Democrat has come up with a comprehensive climate plan which would also bring thousands of jobs across the nation.  People in states like Kentucky and West Virginia should be running to vote for the candidates proposing this instead of relying on completely false promises provided by Trump of bringing back coal. text: ¬†@Eye Minor¬† I don't think you caught my tone. I said that engineers think of an engineered solution as the ONLY one. This is silly to think that everyone can continue to consume more and we will simply use technology to fill in the blanks. As an electrical engineer, I do understand. Take heating for example; try to heat your big@$$ house explicitly with electricity, and then also add heating your hot water to the mix. If you have a 1500W (which all real heaters are) heater in every room and have, say, 8 rooms in the home (3 bed, 2 bath, kitchen, dining room, living room), that's 12000 watts just for heating rooms, then the 9000 watts for your water tank. That's 21000 watts for heating alone. Most solar setups for homes don't exceed 10000 watts. Also, homes consume energy most when the sun is not up, meaning you have to store the amount of excess energy in batteries, or a form of potential energy other than that... Now I know that heaters and hot water aren't always on, but say if they were to all come on at once, you would need a 175 Amp service feed coming into your home on 120V (actually 87.5A on three phase 240V) and would need... wait for it... to draw 1750 amps from a 12V battery setup, and on a more practical setup 437 amps from a 48 V setup. It's literally impractical, bordering nearly impossible. What I'm trying to say is that if we wait for the engineering solution to account for 100% of the solution, we've waited too long and won't be able to fix things... as an engineer.

author: Monocausal

text: ¬†@Monocausal¬† I think I understand what you mean. What I understand through my years upon years of University is that 90% of engineers don't actually do the work because they intrinsically believe in the work they do; they do it for the money. So many of my peers didn't talk about what they would do after they left University and how they could impact the world; they talked about how much money they could make once they left school. They weren't interested in saving the planet; they were interested in buying cars and properties. I think it's cool that these old engineers are trying to help out now in their senior years, but we don't need a few octogenarians donating their time; we need tens of thousands of young engineers dedicating their lives to the cause. They won't though because there just isn't money in saving the world.... yet. I know everyone is going to jump down my throat over that last comment: don't you know how much money is in solar panels and wind turbines!!!??? To which I reply: don't you know that the video game industry is far bigger than either of these industries, that the USA spends around $700 billion every year on its military (and the world about $2 trillion); the global oil industry is worth nearly $1.7 trillion while the global Solar panel industry is worth only about $50 billion. More engineers are going into the defense sector and into the petro-chemical industry.... so I would posit that engineers are more aligned with destroying the world than saving it.

text:
Why don't you do an even better video on this? You could ask tough questions, not just about SAI-SRM, but about everything else too. And arrive at a more accurate balance of understanding of the issue.
There are tough questions crying out to be asked about the feasibility of the near-immediate emissions cessation and arrival at negative-emissions that is being described as needed for stopping the warming and its feedback loops; and whether that would be sufficient even if in theory feasible. There are tough questions crying out to be asked about the probable actual consequences are of such catastrophic reductions, which could include societal upheavals, leading to wars and greater emissions and abandonment of the whole program.  There are tough questions crying out to be asked about the actual meaning of the emission reductions programs, when they are at the same time obstructing and often shuttering nuclear energy, the most effective available method for emissions reductions. There are tough questions about the costs and energy needed for carbon capture and storage, suggesting it may become scalable only after we harness fusion energy to power it.
 Also, there are tough questions about the consequences of the failure to research, test, and implement solar radiation geoengineering (SAI-SRM) fast enough. What will be the effects, as the warming feedback loops keep operating? What would be the optimal timeframe for doing SAI-SRM , weighing the costs of further delay versus the costs of imperfect preparation? What have been the costs already of the long delay on testing and implementing it? Will further delay in the Western part of the world lead to incompetent and geopolitically competing SAI-SRM deployments by other countries? This risk of competing SRM programs is something that you treat, illogically, as if it were to be blamed on SAI-SRM research, rather than on its delay and the ideological pressures against ever doing it. The basics have been known of how to do SAI-SRM for decades.  It should be obvious that, as the warming continues and countries get more desperate, some are going to go ahead with it. If we keep dithering on it, the most desperate countries and least prepared countries will inevitably be the ones to go ahead with it. And then others really will take their own geoengineering measures in response. The only thing that could seem to stop this kind of competition is for the West to hurry up, start preparing seriously for doing it competently, and start building the needed international support to keep it to a single program. 
You could be asking all these questions. It would make for a more honest video. But I do appreciate the fact that you've already had to overcome a lot of entrenched prejudices just to make this one.

text:
The mindset of liberals who refuse to even consider the possibility that maybe we need to address the structural, systemic problems inherent to capitalism that drive not only emission of greenhouse gasses, but producing toxic chemicals that go into the water, air, and consumer products (Johnson & Johnson just was discovered for putting asbestos in their baby powder, a huge proportion of popular baby foods contain arsenic, Taco Bell cut their meat with silica and dusting agents‚Äî the list is endless‚Äî and then there‚Äôs the toxic waste and chemicals like C8 that get dumped into our water and end up in toxic concentrations in almost all of our bodies, rising cancer rates). Depleting vital resources, destroying important ecosystems and biomes, wiping out species so fast that we‚Äôre in a mass extinction event...

It‚Äôs important that we pursue technologies that can help‚Äî we MUST transition to a green energy infrastructure (we literally just can not afford to keep burning fossil fuels), and at the same time, we NEED to develop materials and devices that can suck a lot of CO2 out of the atmosphere, because by all account we have to achieve net negative emissions (at this point within ~10-11 years) to stop climate change from spiraling out of control before it‚Äôs too late. And that‚Äôs all just to address climate change alone.

It‚Äôs delusional to pretend that we can address ALL of these myriad environmental crises without dealing with the systemic root of the systemic problem, or that you‚Äôll find some silver bullet like geoengineering that will make all this go away without us having to think about that aspect. And yet I‚Äôve never seen Vice, or CNN, or MSNBC, or Fox, or Vox, etc., do videos reporting on whether we should be coming up with an alternative to capitalism that won‚Äôt destroy the planet. I wonder why that is... Could it be because these are huge corporations owned primarily by wealthy (disproportionately billionaire/hundred-millionaire) investors, who are part of the tiny percentage of the population who profits ENORMOUSLY and enjoys a position of ruling class power & control over large swaths of the economy predicated on maintaining this system, even if it destroys us in the middle-to-long-term? Hmm. 

Just like the oil corporations place profit over the future of humanity and will continue to suck oil out of the ground and put it into the air until the day there‚Äôs none left, knowing fully well that it will be an end of days scenario if they do‚Äî all other corporations have the same kind of stake in maintaining capitalism as a mode of production, and to the extent that the structures, incentives, institutional imperatives, processes, and social relations of capitalism are causing our ecological catastrophes (I‚Äôd say they 80% of the source of the problem), by continuing to place short-term profits over human well-being, over the decent survival of the species, over sustaining the environment we live in, they are playing an instrumental role in the degradation of our future just like the oil companies. The role of media in this is unique, because when they‚Äôre the ones playing this role, the consequence is that they put out content that manipulates the masses into complacency, into not doing anything about it. The message is essentially ‚ÄúWell, if there‚Äôs a solution it‚Äôll be some scientists somewhere else making a new technology or geoengineering our way out of it‚Äî so just keep recycling your toilet paper tubes and shopping at ‚Äòeco-friendly‚Äô corporations and you‚Äôre doing all you can,‚Äù when the reality is that pursuing necessary social system/policy changes will very likely make or break our future. Corporations, even the nice ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù ones, will never tell you that.

text: Nope. Wrong. Capitalism is great. The only down side to capitalism is the inherent quality of life improvements it bestows on low IQ individuals so they are capable of regurgitating idiocy 18th century failed economic theories to one another on Cattube.
author: Y T

text:
Y T Y T Oh my mistake, hadn‚Äôt thought about it like that. üôÑ

You do realize that anti-capitalist theories arose as a reaction to capitalism... Meaning, that capitalism and capitalist theories came first. So laughing them off as ‚Äú18th century‚Äù is pretty funny. Just like capitalist theory, anti-capitalist theory has been continuing to develop for the last 250 years. But you would have to actually have bothered to familiarize yourself with that body of work to know that. 

I absolutely agree that capitalism has some good qualities and has done some good things. Karl f*cking Marx agreed about that. What capitalists don‚Äôt have a theory or appreciation of is that capitalism was just one more step forward in a process of historical development that started with the rise of civilization and slave economies, through feudal economies, through capitalist economies, and there‚Äôs no reason to believe that process will stop there, any more than feudal lords were right to claim that anyone going on about capitalism were delusional idealists, and actually society would always be feudal. History is on the side of those who recognize that.

The unfortunate reality that your Pinkers and Miseses and Friedmans and Hayeks insist on putting on blinders to is that, along with the production of unprecedented wealth, capitalism has also produced an unprecedented form of mass poverty, where even in one of the richest countries of the world, a huge proportion of the population is below or barely skimming the surface of an already misleadingly low poverty line, where most people will go bankrupt if they have a single injury, illness, or other hospitalization because of a capitalist, for-profit healthcare industry. Capitalism is trending towards working poverty for many‚Äî a condition where even if they work full-time it‚Äôs not enough to survive. I know many people who are having to work 80-100 hours a week like this is Dickensian England, because real wages have been falling for 50 years under policies far more free-market oriented than the social democratic ones capitalism flourished under from the end of WWII to the early 70s. Capitalists as a class have been leveraging their political power to totally marginalize workers (the majority of people) from having political representation, they crushed the labor unions that enabled workers to even negotiate a decent standard of living. 

If you actually develop a materialist analysis of capitalist institutions and how capitalism works, all of this, all the data we have to work with about how our economic history has unfolded, makes perfect sense. It all comes back to the social relations intrinsic to the capitalist class system, the profit motive... Right-wingers will come up with these mythologies where actually all that is just ‚Äúcrony capitalism‚Äù and the problem is ‚Äútoo much government,‚Äù but if you think like the major capitalists actually do‚Äî that paradigm completely breaks down. The fact is, if you‚Äôre a capitalist, you benefit from public policy that maximizes your profit (regardless on its effect on anyone and anything else). To shape public policy you need to control the state. So if you can afford to buy influence/control over the state, that‚Äôs what your rational self-interest dictates you should do, and that‚Äôs what they do. That is just the reality of what happens in capitalism based on the principles that make capitalism run. 

Setting mass poverty aside, setting aside the threat to democracy as the state inevitably gets subsumed by billionaires and multinational corporate conglomerations... Capitalism IS destroying the environment and driving climate change. Whatever you think about capitalism, if we let that happen then no amount of ‚Äúprosperity‚Äù or ‚Äútechnological innovation‚Äù or ‚Äúmarket efficiency‚Äù will matter, because it will ruin life as we know it. 

I have read many different capitalist theories. I have read many different anti-capitalist theories. I have read about the various alternatives. I‚Äôve done my due diligence and come to an informed conclusion. And in my experience, 98% of the people who make vacuous surface level arguments like the ones you‚Äôre making just don‚Äôt have a lot of frame of reference. They learned the most basic principles of Econ 101, they heard one particular version of capitalist theory and all the assumptions that go with it, and they just took that to be God‚Äôs truth, unquestionable science no different from physics. This is delusion and it is delusion largely brought on by dogmatism (an unwillingness to challenge or even recognize your own ideological assumptions, or even that those assumptions are ideological and not objective realities) and an unwillingness to actually expose themselves to opposing theories in good faith, with the genuine desire to arrive at the best possible understanding of the world. Most of the people who prattle on about how socialism means state control, and communism is totalitarianism, and capitalists/corporations/capitalism represent freedom and are totally at odds with the state, and that people who have contrary analyses just ‚Äúdon‚Äôt understand economics‚Äù hold those beliefs because they haven‚Äôt learned enough theories of capitalism to realize how much they don‚Äôt know, and how much the jury is still out on. Even within pro-capitalist spheres, you have neoclassicism, Austrian, Keynesian, social democratic... Many capitalists themselves disagree with your assumptions about capitalism.  But people in institutional roles of power as capitalists are bound by the need to compete, which means to maximize profit and accumulate capital, so even when they recognize the very real (and tbh in most cases obvious) problems I‚Äôm bringing up, they can‚Äôt act differently in their roles as CEOs or board members to solve these problems. And the people who control the state, who are financed by the wealthiest capitalists, their donors in our privately financed electoral system, so they can‚Äôt or won‚Äôt break out of that to solve these problems either. They both benefit from maximizing their own profits at our expense, and if that means driving us off a cliff as far as climate change is concerned, then that‚Äôs what will happen. Oil industrialists won‚Äôt stop of their own volition, and the corporate bag-men they pay to serve them in government won‚Äôt either. As long as we refuse to look at that reality, we‚Äôll edge closer to the point of no return and jeopardize all of our and our descendants‚Äô futures. 

The only left-wing economic theory I see that has failed on a large scale for economic reasons has been the kind of state-capitalism that Leninist-derived authoritarian states have implemented‚Äî in the USSR, in China, etc.. But as a left-libertarian who opposes that and has a whole different theory of what we should be moving towards, I have no problem criticizing that‚Äî I find Leninism and it‚Äôs antecedents extremely destructive and counterproductive to the goal of achieving a stateless, worker-run society. It just installs a new ruling class, the class who controls the state, and puts them in charge of the economy.

Various historical left-libertarian movements have not failed because of economic inadequacy‚Äî in fact, studies of the kinds of worker co-ops that would make up a substantial part of a worker-owner economy show that they‚Äôre more resilient and in many instances more productive than corporations. These revolutions have virtually always been crushed by military force by states who didn‚Äôt want examples to emerge which demonstrate that people can live effectively, prosperously, and freely in the absence of coercive, exploitative, and authoritarian institutions and ruling classes. It was capitalist republics alongside fascist states and the Soviet Union who historically played the biggest roles in sniffing these movements, which had real potential, out. But we continue to learn from history and adapt, to understand how to better defend the seedlings of a decent future society.

At the end of the day, if you don‚Äôt see the suffering taking place because of the form and dynamics of capitalism, you have to be incredibly insulated from it, because it affects most of the population to some extent or another (many of them horrifically). But you‚Äôd have to be a billionaire to be that far removed from the reality most people face. Far more likely is that you‚Äôve just bought into the ruling class mythology: ‚ÄúOh, sure, there are (massive numbers of) people suffering and toiling in our economy... Bit it‚Äôs actually because of ‚Äòtoo much‚Äô government [an argument immediately debunked by history]. Or it‚Äôs okay because it wouldn‚Äôt been worse without capitalism, so we shouldn‚Äôt try to improve the systemic roots of the problems.‚Äù Or ‚Äúit‚Äôs all totally ‚Äòvoluntary‚Äô when propertyless workers agree to work on someone else‚Äôs command for someone else‚Äôs profit because they know that if they don‚Äôt they‚Äôll starve/go homeless/get sick and die.‚Äù Nothing at all coercive about agreeing to serve someone because you know you‚Äôll die if you don‚Äôt. Totally free, ideal arrangement, that. But then, the same right-wing libertarians who buy that also often argue that a parent has every right to sell their child into slavery, and has no problem with the development of totally unaccountable private tyrannies which can do virtually whatever they want to rip workers, communities, and the environment we all depend on apart, because their ‚Äúright‚Äù to do so is the highest form of freedom.

text:
Some of you are saying, "Good.  Mar-el-lago will be underwater".    lol


It's funny how a tiny handful of coastal communities seem to be flooding but not all of them.  That's a problem when you consider the fact that there is only one body of water on earth.  This way of thinking is as stupid as thinking that by filling up a bucket with water from the deep end of a pool, and emptying it in the shallow end, the shallow end will become progressively deeper while the deep end becomes progressively more shallow.  It doesn't work like that,  


However, a lot of places are actually sinking. And some are rising.  This IS nature.  It has always been happening and always will.    

I have my B.S. in BioChem from Yale, Masters in Environmental Science from UW Madison, and a PhD in BioPhysics from the University of Minnesota.  I am also a writer.   My first paid writing gig was at age 17 with the Cedar Rapids Gazette.  I have since worked for dozens of media (print and tv) outlets around the world.  

A friend of mine did a piece about 6 months ago for the NY Times, i believe, that reported a temperature increase of some 50F within 24 hours at a location in the arctic.  It was true.  He didn't lie.  But what he didn't tell you was that there had been nearly 3 months of record cold in the area, and the day that this temperature increase was measured it had only brought temps up to normal for the region for that part of the year.  Global Warming?   lol.    Yep.   And don't forget it!

text:
The obvious political, financial, and religious motives for spreading climate hysteria are the real drivers of our irrational anti-carbon policies, not science.   Apocalyptic doomsday religions have been popular since the dawn of man, and climate hysteria is an ancient phenomenon that has plagued our past.  Five hundred years ago the weather was so extreme that Europeans burned alive thousands of people accused of being "weather witches." Through "weather cooking" they were believed to have caused terrifying storms that destroyed crops and killed farm animals. Only a few citizens objected to burning their neighbors and using torture to gain confessions. The dissenters believed that weather is controlled by Nature, not by man. If you express those exact sentiments today even United States senators and congressmen will brand you a "denier," a term historically used in different forms by virtually all intolerant religions around the world.  See Dr. Baliunas on Weather Cooking (YouTube video).

     Scientists ‚Äî devout true believers ‚Äî at NASA, NOAA, and the IPCC have been caught distorting data to increase our level of anxiety.  You can argue with science, but you cannot argue with religious fervor.  Thus, we see the Orwellian spectacle of Americans protesting ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù during record cold and snow, and after Niagara Falls froze two winters in a row.  Humans are 18.5% carbon by weight, eat carbon based food, and live in homes made with carbon.  A war against carbon is a war against the essential fuel of life our own families.

author: Nicolas Palomino

text:
¬†@Nicolas Palomino¬† Sure, I'll just sum it up for you as well. To be clear im not saying it can't be done, just that it isnt effective. Basically it's been known for the better part of the last century that pumping fluid or gas back into crust creats fissures in the rock that lead to quakes. Think fracking here, same concept. In order for the recapture to be effective Co2 needs to be held out of the atmosphere for thousands of years. Because these fissures are highly unstable they coukd leak Co2 constantly and that basically renders the whole process a wash. It becomes a big waste of effort time and money. 

Here's some literature:

https://www.climatecentral.org/news/the-earth-shaking-consequences-of-burying-carbon-underground (there's a hyperlink in there with the actual source of the study done, but this article is a good read.)

Also I'd like to point out that there have been new feats accomplished in this field that do allow for safer forms of recapture and burial but none so far have proven to be able to work on a global scale and so although it might work in tandem with say a power plant, its not exactly a viable solution to climate change.
author: Mikerphone

text:
¬†@Mikerphone¬† there's clearly a lot of doubt surrounding the long term viability of storing Co2 in the ground. Most potential solutions to climate change are impractical. But there are no simple or practical ideas to solving climate change. Co2 recapture and burial is one of the better options compared to covering the Arctic with dust or using volcanic Ash... 

Also there has been a lot of research into the long term storage of nuclear waste, progress made in this area might translate into solutions for storing Co2. Let's assume the Co2 is buried and there is a small chance that a fissure could cause a leak back into the atmosphere. If there are hundreds or thousands of these Co2 reservoirs and some of them leak I still believe the effect of the Co2 collection effort would be net positive for the planet.
author: Nicolas Palomino

text:
Alternative proposal. You guys might be aware that the majority of carbon that is removed from the atmosphere naturally is eventually converted via sunlight into particulate complex carbon molecules (through photosynthesis). Much of this carbon capture happens in the oceans, where CO2 dissolves into the ocean water and is converted into biomass by algeas and cyanobacteria, which then eventually sinks to the ocean floor (effectively sequestering it from the carbon cycle for billions of years). 


The Carbon Engineering company is doing something similar; it is using the power of sunlight to convert gaseous carbon into more complex carbon molecules (in this case, fuel). What if, instead of fuel, we produce huge amounts of new biomass, which can then be spread into the oceans and sequestered (i.e. by sinking to the ocean floor, in a similar manner that happens naturally).

author: sharefactor

text:
¬†@Nicolas Palomino¬† When we look at the data of fracking wells and we see how often theses caps fail, and or new fissures outside of the cap expose the surrounding environment to harmful compunds. It becomes a lot clearer that failure is much more of a factor than the likelihood of success. Considering the massive amounts of resources that have to go into the implementation of something like this to meet a scale which could create any noticeable net positive diffrence in the atmosphere. We really need to sit back and do a lot of thinking on rates of success and the risk factors at play. I find that the risk of causing more earthquakes and high likelihood of leaking large amounts of co2 back into the atmosphere far outweighs the endevor into trapping supercritical co2 in the crust. 

If more science comes out on the mineralization and subsequent solidification process. Then at that point im all ears on making this work as a viable solution. Because i do believe that there are practical low risk solutions to geo-engineering. Someone had already mentioned using biomass as a solution. There is a ton of research into that which looks very promising, but there is also a lot to be said about low orbit dispersions and other processes that could be immediately effective in at least cooling the earth. As long as the chemistry pans out, they could also be completely harmless. So why not? 

In conclusion i would say we should always pursue multiple avenues of a solution even when some appear bleak. Though we shouldn't be so hasty to accept those which come with underpinning downsides and risks just because the clock has run out. In the end we may find that it wasted precious resources, time, and ultimately left us either where we were to begin with. Or in an even more unfortunate situation.

author: arslongavitabrebis

text:
1) Yes, spraying salt, in fact any attempt to "engineer" a solution to this problem with result in what are called "unintended consequences". If you study history, you will find out that most of human history is filled with people trying to accomplish one thing and failing and simultaneously causing all kinds of problems in the mean time. A good example of this would be the Army Corp of engineers attempting to keep Niagara Falls from eroding too quickly, so they blocked off the US side of the falls, did a lot of "engineering" and ultimately all the work collapsed and was eroded by mother nature making a mess while the Canadian side of the falls just eroded naturally. Guess which side people consider the majestic natural beauty? (Hint, you'll almost always only see a picture of the Canadian side of Niagara Falls).

2) Most of the CO2 on the planet is absorbed in and out of the oceans. What these clowns don't tell you is that atmospheric CO2 increases AFTER temperature increases according to the historical temperature records (proxy records for millions of years based on ice core samples for example). You're almost onto something in your last sentence. All of this CO2/climate change nonsense is really about money.

3) Volcanic eruptions are natural and unstoppable. They are not good for humans if you're too close, other than that, they're just part of the planet's complicated natural processes that we will never be able to influence. They are a large source of CO2 emissions as well.

The thing to remember is that plants absorb CO2 as food. Greenhouses actually pump in CO2 to have better crop yields. The CO2/climate change hysteria has been going on for a long time under a lot of different names but it's generally all about people who are nihilistic, overestimate their own personal significance in the universe (in terms of affecting the entire world). They focus on imaginary global problems instead of being good responsible people in their own lives and to their own families and communities, don't forget that.

text:
Wheat and maize. Some of the time they allowed cows to roam over the fields to increase the fertilizer. When we did not have cows, we get their waste from the feedlots.

As to what animals want. They want to eat, drink and increase their numbers. The last time the area I live in had natural trees (as opposed to us planting them) the temperature was about 10¬∞C warmer. What is most interesting is those trees are still there but due to the winter cold killing them off every year, they never get more than a yard or so tall. We call them weeds. There never was a need to clear cut any forest here.

The vast majority of clear cutting forest occurred before 1900. What we have done is to change the "great American desert" into farmland.

Yes we have an effect on the earth, but not as negative as you assume and not with co2. The only thing co2 has been proven to do is to increase the green of the earth. In 33 years, instead of turning brown as the alarmist claimed, it has gotten 17% greener and is continuing to do so.

text:
It's funny how a tiny handful of coastal communities seem to be flooding but not all of them.  That's kind of a problem when you consider the fact that there is only one body of water on earth.  This way of thinking is as stupid as thinking that by filling up a bucket with water from the deep end of a pool, and emptying it in the shallow end, the shallow end will become progressively deeper while the deep end becomes shallow.  A lot of places are actually sinking, though.   Some are rising.  This IS nature.  It's always been happening.    


I have my B.S. in BioChem from Yale, Masters in Environmental Science from UW Madison, and a PhD in BioPhysics from the University of Minnesota.  I am also a writer.   My first paid writing gig was at age 17 with the Cedar Rapids Gazette.  I have since worked for dozens of media (print and tv) outlets around the world.  


A friend of mine did a piece about 6 months ago that reported a temperature increase of some 50F within 24 hours at a location in the arctic.  It was true.  He didn't lie.  But what he didn't tell you was that there had been nearly 3 months of record cold in the area, and the day that this temperature increase was measured it had only brought temps up to normal for the region during that part of the year.  Global Warming?   lol.    Yep.   And don't forget it!
